title-group.article-title: The attachment of intrinsic and extrinsic, mobilized and immobilized adhesion cells to collagen and fibronectin

abstract.p: This study investigated the attachment of intrinsic and extrinsic, mobilized and immobilized adhesion cells to the extracellular matrix. Five New Zealand White rabbit forepaws were dissected to isolate the flexor tendon core, tendon surface and synovial sheath, which were explanted separately. A further 10 animals were subjected to flexor tendon injuries, randomized to either mobilization or immobilization, and adhesions were explanted at 2 weeks. Cell groups were tested for attachment to collagen type-I or fibronectin and morphometric analysis was made. The attachment of intrinsic tendon cells and adhesion cells from mobilized tendons to both matrix proteins was statistically significantly greater than that of extrinsic tendon cells and adhesion cells from immobilized tendons. Adhesion cells from mobilized tendons were statistically significantly more elongated, which may correlate with the deposition of a more organized matrix. Because the synovial sheath cells were least attached to matrix proteins, selective treatments that reduce cell attachment may be used to exclude them, without inhibiting intrinsic tendon healing.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Cells contributing to tendon healing and adhesion formation are either intrinsic to tendon (Gelberman et al., 1991; Lundborg and Rank, 1978; Manske et al., 1984; Matthews, 1976) or extrinsic to it, arising from synovial sheath (Harrison et al., 2003; Potenza, 1962, 1963; Skoog and Persson, 1954). However, it is widely regarded as impossible using existing strategies to isolate the contributions of these cells to healing in the clinical setting (Strickland, 2000).

Various anti-adhesive treatments have previously been studied. These often reduce the adhesion response at the expense of impairing healing in the tendon, thereby favouring tendon rupture (Golash et al., 2003). The authors in the present study have recently demonstrated, using a biomaterial that reduces cell attachment, that it may be possible to target post-surgical adhesions without compromising tendon cellularity (Branford et al., 2008, 2010).

The aims of the present study were first to determine whether there was a difference in cell attachment between cells of different origins from within the digital tendon-synovial complex to collagen and fibronectin in vitro, and second to determine whether mobilization had an effect on the attachment of cells contributing to the formation of tendon adhesions. Cell shape is a function of cell behaviour and reflects the distribution of focal adhesion complexes and therefore cell attachment (Lee et al., 2006; Li et al., 2008; McBeath et al., 2004; Singhvi et al., 1994; Wang et al., 2003; Yang et al., 2004). Therefore the attachment of tendon core, tendon surface, synovial sheath, mobilized and immobilized adhesion cells to collagen and fibronectin was investigated using both morphometric analysis (the quantitative analysis of cell size and shape) and attachment assays.

sec.title: Fibroblast culture
sec.p: Five New Zealand White rabbit right forepaws were dissected using a Zeiss operating microscope (Carl Zeiss, Oberkochen, Germany), separating the flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) tendons from the synovial sheath in digits two and four. Tendons were stripped of their surface using a scalpel. Thus, components of the deep digital flexor tendon-synovial complex were separated into tendon core, tendon surface, and synovial sheath. These were washed in saline, explanted separately and maintained in culture in Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium (DMEM; including penicillin–streptomycin (100 U/ml and 100 µg/ml, respectively), l-glutamine (2 mmol/l), 10% foetal calf serum (all from Gibco, Paisley, UK).

sec.title: Tendon injury model
sec.p: A further 10 animals were subjected to FDP tendon injuries, and then randomized to mobilization or immobilization as follows. All animal care and procedures complied with the guidelines of the authors’ institutions and the UK Home Office’s Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals (1996), under licence of the Department of Health. Surgery was conducted under general anaesthesia on the second and fourth digits of the right forepaw in 10 New Zealand White male rabbits (weight, 2.4–3.3 kg) using a Zeiss operating microscope, according to the method previously described (Branford et al., 2008). An incision was made proximal to the A1 pulley to gain access to the FDP tendon. This approach avoided direct injury to the synovial sheath. A one-third thickness 5 mm long partial tenotomy injury was made. Partial tendon transections circumvent the need for suture repair and allow for immediate post-operative tendon mobilization (Chan et al., 1998; Kubota et al., 1996). The tendon was then returned to the neutral position within the sheath. Animals were randomized either to mobilized or immobilized groups. Tendons were immobilized by proximal complete transection (Jones et al., 2002). After recovery, animals were allowed to move about as normal. Animals were sacrificed at 14 days using barbiturate injection and adhesions harvested and explanted as described above. Cells were tested using both attachment assays and morphometric analysis.

sec.title: Cell adhesion assay
sec.p: Collagen type-I (First Link, Brierley Hill, UK) and fibronectin (Sigma-Aldrich, Poole, UK) were diluted in ice cold phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) (Sigma-Aldrich, Poole, UK) and aliquoted into high-binding Nunc MaxiSorp 96 well ELISA plates (Nunc, Paisley, UK) at 0, 1, 2, 6, 12, 25 and 50 µg/ml. Each well was reproduced in quadruplicate. Proteins were allowed to adsorb for 1 hour at 37°C. Wells were washed with PBS to remove unattached protein. Cells at passage three or four were washed with Versene (Gibco, Paisley, UK) then harvested using Accutase (Gibco, Paisley, UK), then re-suspended in DMEM with 0.01% BSA. 2 × 106 cells/cm2 were seeded per well in 100 µl DMEM with 0.01% BSA and allowed to attach for 1 hour at 37°C. Control wells contained DMEM with 0.01% BSA only without cells. Wells were washed twice using 100 µl PBS. Adherent cells were fixed and stained using 25 µl 0.5% crystal violet solution (BDH Merck, Poole, UK), 5% formol-saline, 50% ethanol, 0.85% sodium chloride) and incubated for 10 minutes at 37°C. The crystal violet was aspirated using a fine needle and wells were washed twice with PBS.

sec.title: Cell adhesion assessment
sec.p: Bound crystal violet was dissolved with 33% acetic acid. Absorbance was measured in a microplate reader at 595 nm. Absorbance was calculated as the mean of the quadruplicate cell values, corrected for background absorbance (the absorbance of the control wells was subtracted) and expressed for each matrix protein for each cell group.

sec.title: Morphological assessment
sec.p: Digital images taken at random of cells attached to either collagen or fibronectin at 25 µg/ml were captured using a ×20 lens with an Axioskop inverted optical microscope (Carl Zeiss, Oberkochen, Germany). Cell area, perimeter and circularity were quantified using Image J software (US National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, Maryland) (Ng et al., 2005; Papadopulos et al., 2007). Each micrograph image was first converted into a binary image using the threshold function; these were then despeckled, the watershed function applied to delineate apposed cells, and processed using established macros (Ng et al., 2005). All cells in each image (typically 10 to 100 cells) were evaluated. Particle counting was used to determine the number of elongated or circular cells.

sec.title: Statistical assessment
sec.p: Cell attachment data was compared using two-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) with the Tukey post-test. Morphological data was compared using Student’s t-test for adhesion cell groups (the Mann–Whitney U-test was used when data was not normally distributed) and using a two-way ANOVA with Dunnett’s post-test for tendon-synovial complex cell groups. The p-value was considered statistically significant if < 0.05.

sec.title: Cell adhesion assessment
sec.p: Absorbance of crystal violet was measured in quadruplicate in a microplate reader at 595 nm. Corrected values were expressed for each matrix protein for tendon-synovial complex cell groups and for adhesion cell groups.

sec.title: Tendon-synovial complex cell groups
sec.p: Cell attachment for each of the tendon core, tendon surface and synovial sheath cell groups at 0 to 50 µg/ml for collagen type-I (Figure 1; Table 1) and fibronectin (Figure 2; Table 2) are shown. The results indicate that cell attachment was greatest for tendon core cells and lowest for synovial sheath cells for both matrix proteins for all concentrations tested. The attachment of tendon surface cells was consistently between that of tendon core and synovial sheath cell groups. The difference in mean absorbance values, representing cell attachment, to both collagen-I and fibronectin among the different cell groups was statistically significant (p < 0.001).

sec.p: Immobilized adhesion cells had a 26% greater area (p = 0.069), 6% greater perimeter (p = 0.733) and were 8% more circular (p = 0.300) than mobilized adhesion cells on collagen type-I. Mobilized adhesions expressed 300% more cells with elongated morphology than immobilized adhesions (p = 0.004).

Immobilized adhesions had a 9% greater area (p = 0.717), 1% greater perimeter (p = 0.974) and were 6% more circular (p = 0.440) than mobilized adhesion cells on fibronectin. Mobilized adhesions expressed 68% more cells with an elongated morphology relative to immobilized adhesions (p = 0.046).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Various methods for modifying flexor tendon adhesion formation have previously been investigated. They may be categorized as either biochemical agents, such as non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agents, hyaluronic acid, and 5-fluorouracil (Khan et al., 2000; Salti et al., 1993; Tan et al., 2010) or physical barriers, such as polytetrafluoroethylene, ADCON® T/N (Gliatech, Cleveland, Oklahoma, USA), Seprafilm® Bioresorbable Membrane (Genzyme, Oxford, UK), and phospholipid polymer hydrogel (Golash et al., 2003; Hanff and Hagberg, 1998; Ishiyama et al., 2010; Yilmaz et al., 2010). However, none of these treatments are used routinely after tendon repair. The problem is how to selectively favour intrinsic tendon healing while reducing the formation of restrictive adhesions (Lin et al., 2004). The treatment strategies that have previously been described are not specific in selecting for cells of a particular origin. The authors of the present study have recently demonstrated that it may be possible to reduce post-surgical adhesions without compromising tendon cellularity, using a biomaterial that appears to reduce cell attachment, (Branford et al., 2008, 2010).

In this study we examined the attachment of the different components of the tendon-synovial complex and healing adhesions to collagen type-I and fibronectin. The study aims were to determine if there was a difference in cell attachment between cells of different origins from within the digital tendon-synovial complex to collagen and fibronectin, and to determine if mobilization had an effect on the attachment of cells contributing to tendon adhesion formation.

The attachment of intrinsic tendon cells (tendon core and tendon surface cells) was statistically significantly greater than that of extrinsic tendon cells (synovial sheath cells) to both collagen type-I and fibronectin at all concentrations tested. This difference in attachment was not reflected in changes in cell morphology with regards to cell area, perimeter or percentage of cells with an elongated or circular morphology on either collagen type-I or fibronectin.

The flexor tendon synovial sheath demonstrates a vigorous inflammatory response after injury to the flexor tendon (Khan et al., 1996), with increased cell proliferation relative to the tendon itself (Kakar et al., 1998). Previous studies suggest that synovial sheath fibroblasts contribute actively to adhesion formation as a result of their capacity to degrade the extracellular matrix, their greater fibronectin production rate and their ability to contract a collagen lattice (Brigman et al., 1994; Kakar et al., 1998; Khan et al., 1996, 1997; Klein et al., 2001; Ragoowansi et al., 2003). Khan and colleagues (1998) demonstrated that synovial sheath fibroblasts are more active migrators than tendon fibroblasts. In the present study synovial sheath fibroblasts expressed the lowest attachment. Cell migration is regulated through adhesive interactions between the cells and the cell substratum. Although cell attachment is a prerequisite for migration (van der Flier and Sonnenberg, 2001), with increasing adhesiveness the forces are insufficient to break the attachments between the cells and substratum, leaving cells incapable of locomotion (Huttenlocher et al., 1995). At lower adhesiveness cytoskeletal forces are roughly in balance with adhesion so that traction can be maintained at the front of the cell while it can be disrupted at the rear of the cell, permitting net cell body movement (DiMilla et al., 1993). The synovial sheath cells, being more active migrators, therefore show less attachment than tendon cells. The implication of the results of the present study is that as synovial sheath cells are least avidly attached, then the prevention of attachment, or detachment, of these cells may be a suitable target for selective biological treatment.

In this study, the attachment of mobilized adhesion cells was statistically significantly greater than that of immobilized adhesion cells to both collagen type-I and fibronectin at all concentrations tested. Mobilized adhesion cells expressed a statistically significantly greater percentage of elongated cells to both collagen type-I and fibronectin than did immobilized adhesion cells. The present study appears to confirm that synovial sheath cells contribute disproportionately to adhesions, and therefore tendon healing, when digits are immobilized, as demonstrated by the poorer attachment and therefore greater migration of adhesion cells. Conversely, intrinsic cells appear to be favoured in mobilized adhesions, where cells were found to be more elongated and showed greater attachment.

The effect of mobilization on tendon healing is well documented: adhesions are reduced and tendon tensile properties are enhanced (Birdsell et al., 1966; Gelberman et al., 1982, 1986; Kubota et al., 1996; Munro et al., 1970). Mobilization may result in increased cellular activity, collagen and glycosaminoglycan content in tendons, whereas immobilization may cause increased collagen degradation and a reduction in proline and sulphate incorporation. However, the effect of mobilization on cell attachment has not been previously investigated.

Previous studies have shown that cell attachment and morphology is related to gene expression and protein production, implying a cell shape-based regulation of cellular function (Lee et al., 2006; McBeath et al., 2004; Singhvi et al., 1994). Li and colleagues (2008) showed that elongated human tendon cells expressed 65% greater collagen type-I than circular cells with the same cell area, indicating that tendon cells in vivo, which assume an elongated shape in normal tendons, have an ‘optimal shape’ to perform their major function, that is, to synthesize collagen type I. By producing collagen type I, tendon cells in vivo function to maintain, repair and remodel tendon matrix (Yang et al., 2004). Li et al. (2008) demonstrated that elongated cells have focal adhesions that were concentrated at their two ends, whereas in circular cells, focal adhesions were uniformly distributed along the circumference of the cell. The observation that cell shape determines the distribution of focal adhesion complex formation may explain why these elongated tendon cells produce aligned collagen matrix in vitro and in vivo (Li et al., 2008; Wang et al., 2003). In the present study, mobilization favoured the formation of elongated cells, which may explain why mobilized tendons demonstrate improved tensile properties.

The results of the present study confirm the results of a previous study in which synovial sheath fibroblasts had a lower attachment efficiency than did tendon cells, although the study examined attachment to tissue culture plastic and not to matrix proteins (Riederer-Henderson et al., 1983). The study did not examine all the components of the tendon-synovial complex and did not assess adhesion cells or the effect of mobilization on cell phenotype. However, such studies add to data indicating that not all fibroblasts have identical phenotypes. The variation in phenotypic expression of fibroblasts from the tendon-synovial complex has not been extensively investigated, and this information may prove useful for optimizing future repair strategies (Sharma and Maffulli, 2005).

Previous studies suggest that synovial sheath cells secrete fibronectin, in contrast to tendon fibroblasts (Banes et al., 1988; Brigman et al., 1994). Conversely, synovial sheath cells produce less collagen than tendon cells (Berglund et al., 2004; Riederer-Henderson et al., 1983). Fibronectin is a key cell adhesion molecule secreted by wound fibroblasts. It is released during the early phases of wound healing. Fibroblasts attach to fibronectin, then lay down collagen as they migrate over it. This process of fibrosis ultimately leads to the formation of adhesions (Gelberman et al., 1991; Grinnell, 1984). As healing progresses the extracellular matrix changes from being fibronectin rich to collagen rich. There is therefore a shift in the composition of the extracellular matrix over time. As synovial sheath cells produce proportionately more fibronectin than tendon cells there is also a spatial gradient, from an outer fibronectin rich environment to a collagenous environment closer to the tendon (Berglund et al., 2006; Wong et al., 2009). Therefore, preventing the attachment of poorly adherent cells (such as synovial sheath fibroblasts) to fibronectin during the early stages of healing may be a suitable target for selective inhibition within the tendon healing complex, the ultimate aim of tendon healing strategies. This may explain the results of our previous work, which demonstrated a significant reduction in the restrictive nature of post-surgical adhesions after treatment without compromising tendon cellularity, using a biomaterial that appears to prevent the attachment of fibroblasts to fibronectin (Branford et al., 2008, 2010). Shimo-Oka and colleagues (1998) have previously demonstrated that human fibroblasts have differential properties when attaching to matrix proteins. The production of a fibronectin fragment following trypsinization inhibited fibroblasts from attaching and spreading onto fibronectin, without inhibiting attachment to collagen. If a treatment favours intrinsic cell attachment to collagen over that of synovial sheath cell attachment to fibronectin, it may encourage healing and the restoration of gliding surface while preventing the laying down of the adhesion bridge over a fibronectin scaffold.

Flexor tendon adhesion formation continues to be a significant and unsolved problem. The selection of intrinsic tendon healing over extrinsic tendon healing has not been possible, except by the use of regimes of rehabilitation. This is the first study to demonstrate that the attachment of intrinsic tendon cells is significantly greater than the attachment of extrinsic tendon cells to both collagen type-I and fibronectin. This study has shown that mobilization favours the contribution of cells with the greatest attachment to the healing process. Adhesion cells from mobilized tendons also expressed a statistically significantly greater percentage of elongated type cells attached to both collagen type-I and fibronectin than did adhesion cells from immobilized tendons. This study suggests that the differential avidity of cell attachment within the healing tendon-synovial complex is a potential target for new anti-adhesive strategies that favour the contribution of intrinsic cells to tendon healing while minimizing the contribution of extrinsic tendon cells, thereby reducing the formation of restrictive adhesions. As synovial sheath cells demonstrate poorer attachments to extracellular matrix than tendon cells, selective treatments may be developed that reduce cell attachment and preferentially exclude extrinsic cells, without inhibiting the contribution of intrinsic tendon cells to healing.
